skill.name: mcp-server
skill.description: Generic MCP (Model Context Protocol) server development patterns. Provides reusable architecture and best practices for building MCP servers that expose any domain-specific operations as tools for AI agents. Framework-agnostic implementation supporting async operations, error handling, and enterprise-grade features.

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing example Python code patterns for building MCP servers. No executable code, no network calls to external endpoints, no file system access beyond its own markdown content, and no malicious capabilities detected.

content.value_statement: Creating MCP servers from scratch requires understanding protocol patterns, database integration, and enterprise features. This skill provides reusable architecture patterns so you can build production-ready MCP servers faster.
actual_capabilities: Provides base MCP server architecture with rate limiting and caching
Offers database integration patterns for PostgreSQL, MongoDB, and Redis
Delivers reusable CRUD and bulk operation tool patterns
Includes testing patterns and mock implementations
Supports async operations with proper error handling
limitations: Contains example patterns only; you must implement and deploy your own server
Requires external services (Redis, PostgreSQL, MongoDB) for full functionality
No built-in authentication or authorization framework

prompt_templates.title: Basic Server Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the mcp-server skill to create a basic MCP server structure. Show me how to configure the ServerConfig and initialize the BaseMCPServer class.

prompt_templates.title: Add Database Tools
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me add database operations to my MCP server using the database integration patterns. I want to support PostgreSQL with async operations.

prompt_templates.title: Implement CRUD Operations
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to use the CRUDBaseTool pattern to add create, read, update, and delete operations for a custom entity in my MCP server.

prompt_templates.title: Add Rate Limiting
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement rate limiting and caching for my MCP server using the Redis-based patterns from the mcp-server skill.

output_examples.input: Create a new MCP server called 'document-manager' that exposes document CRUD operations
output: Initialize server with ServerConfig specifying name, version, and description
Create DatabaseManager with PostgreSQL backend for document storage
Define document schema with title, content, status, and tags properties
Register CRUD tools using CRUDBaseTool pattern
Configure Redis-based rate limiter with configurable request limits
Add cache manager for read-heavy operations like list_documents

best_practices: Separate concerns: MCP protocol handling, data access layer, and business logic should be independent
Use async operations throughout to support concurrent tool calls efficiently
Validate all tool arguments against schemas before execution to prevent errors
Implement proper error handling with meaningful error messages returned to callers
anti_patterns: Hardcoding database credentials in source code; use environment variables instead
Executing raw user input as code; always validate against schemas
Skipping rate limiting on public MCP servers; this exposes you to abuse
Storing sensitive data in cache without encryption or TTL limits

faq.question: Which databases does this skill support?
faq.answer: PostgreSQL (asyncpg and SQLAlchemy), MongoDB (Motor), and SQLAlchemy with any supported backend.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of tools an MCP server can expose?
faq.answer: The MCP protocol does not impose hard limits, but practical limits depend on memory and response times.

faq.question: Can I use this with Claude Code and other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, MCP servers built with these patterns work with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code clients.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using MCP servers?
faq.answer: Data safety depends on your implementation. This skill provides patterns; you must add authentication.

faq.question: Why is my server not responding to tool calls?
faq.answer: Check that your server is running, Redis/database connections are valid, and tools are properly registered.

faq.question: How does this compare to using a REST API?
faq.answer: MCP provides structured tool definitions and type validation that REST APIs lack, making AI integration simpler.
